senses.de: A relationship between two things or situations.
senses.ex: There is a clear link between poverty and crime.

Tips.title: Abstract Concept
Tips.description: The link here is intangible, showing relationship or relevance between abstract concepts.
Tips.example: She found a link between diet and well-being.

Tips.title: Implicit Cause
Tips.description: Sometimes 'link' indicates an underlying cause, not just a correlation.
Tips.example: Scientists discovered a link between smoking and lung cancer.

Tips.title: Research Context
Tips.description: Often used in academic or research contexts to show findings or hypotheses.
Tips.example: The study explored the link between sleep patterns and learning abilities.

senses.ex: One link of the chain was weak and broke.

Tips.title: Physical Object
Tips.description: This 'link' refers to the physical and visible part of a chain or series.
Tips.example: If a single link in the chain is broken, the entire chain fails.

Tips.title: Strength Metaphor
Tips.description: Used metaphorically to describe the strongest or weakest point in a system or argument.
Tips.example: The weakest link in our team's defense cost us the game.

senses.de: To connect or associate with each other.
senses.ex: The two incidents were quickly linked by the police.

Tips.title: Action of Joining
Tips.description: Emphasizes the act of joining two or more elements together.
Tips.example: You can link your phone to your computer to share files.

Tips.title: Cause and Effect
Tips.description: Can represent a causal relationship, where one action leads to another.
Tips.example: Poor planning was linked to the event's failure.

senses.de: A code allowing a user to go from a webpage or file to another part on the internet.
senses.ex: Click on this link to access the article.

Tips.title: Online Navigation
Tips.description: This 'link' is a tool for navigating between web pages or online content.
Tips.example: Click this link to jump to the registration page.

Tips.title: Shortcut
Tips.description: Links provide a quick way to access information without the need for lengthy searches.
Tips.example: I sent you a link to the article instead of the whole text.

senses.ex: He played a round on the famous St Andrews links.

Tips.title: Golfing Term
Tips.description: Here, 'links' is specific to golf and refers to the type of course.
Tips.example: He enjoys playing on old links courses by the sea.

Tips.title: British Usage
Tips.description: Most common in the UK, 'links' in golf may be less familiar to those outside of Britain.
Tips.example: On our trip to Scotland, we played on a historic links.

Affiliate.wordDefinition:
An affiliate is a person or company that earns a commission by promoting someone else's products or services. They sign up for an affiliate program, and then they share a special link with their audience to promote the product.

When someone clicks on their link and makes a purchase, the affiliate earns a percentage of the sale.

An affiliate is a person who earns money by promoting someone else's product or service, while a link is a clickable element that takes you from one website or page to another.

Affiliates use links to promote products and earn commissions on sales.

Links can be used for a variety of purposes beyond affiliate marketing.

Attach.wordDefinition:
Attach means to physically connect two things. For example, you can attach a document to an email by including it as an attachment.

Attach is used when you want to include a separate file or physical object, while link is used when you want to reference something without including it.

Bond.wordDefinition:
Bond refers to a strong connection between two things or people, like the bond between friends or the bond between atoms in a molecule.

Link refers to a connection between two things, but it may not be as strong or significant as a bond. For example, two websites might be linked, but they don't necessarily have a bond.

A bond is a strong connection that implies closeness, while a link is just a connection between two things or ideas.

Connect.wordDefinition:
Connect means to bring together or join two or more things, ideas, or persons. For example, you can connect a printer to a computer to start printing.

In terms of persons, connect means to establish communication or build a relationship with someone.

Link means to attach or connect one thing to another. For example, you can link a webpage to another by clicking on a hyperlink.

In this case, link refers to establishing a connection between two different things or ideas.

Connect is more often used when referring to people and relationships, while link is more commonly used when referring to technology and information.

Couple.wordDefinition:
Couple refers to two things that are paired together or joined.

It can describe a romantic relationship between two people, but it can also be used in everyday language to mean two things that go together, like a couple of books or a couple of pencils.

Couple is more commonly used to describe a pairing or relationship between two things, while link describes a connection or association between two things, whether they are physical or abstract.

Interconnect.wordDefinition:
Both interconnect and link refer to connecting things together, but interconnect is used when referring to more complex and intricate connections between parts or systems, while link is used for simpler or more direct connections.

For example, a computer's hardware components are interconnected through a complex network of wires, circuits, and interfaces, whereas files on a computer are linked together through simpler processes like hyperlinks.

Interconnect is used for deeper and more complex connections, while link is used for shallower and more straightforward connections.

Join.wordDefinition:
Join refers to two separate things coming together to become one, like pieces of a puzzle fitting together. For example, you can join a club or a team, meaning you become a member of that group.

So, while both words involve bringing things together, join implies becoming a part of something larger, while link implies creating a connection between two separate things.

Link up.wordDefinition:
Link refers to a connection between two things or people.

It can be used in a general sense to describe any type of connection, such as a hyperlink on a website or a physical chain linking two objects together.

The phrase link up means to connect or join together. It usually implies a more intentional and purposeful connection between two or more things or people.

For example, people might link up to collaborate on a project or to meet in person after online communication.

Link refers to a connection while link up describes a deliberate connecting of two or more things or people.

Tie.wordDefinition:
Tie describes a physical or symbolic connection between two or more things. For example, a tie is a piece of clothing worn around the neck that symbolizes a connection to a group or organization.

It can also indicate a close relationship or bond between people, like a family tie.

Link is used more in digital contexts and to describe connections or relationships between abstract concepts. Tie is more likely to be used in physical contexts and to describe connections or relationships between people or things.

quotes.Text: My writing and my paintings do not have a direct connection in my mind. But I am sure they influence each other in the measure that everything we do is linked to whatever we are, which includes whatever we have done or are doing.
quotes.Title: Lebanese Poet
quotes.Name: Etel Adnan

quotes.Text: The truth is that we can learn to condition our minds, bodies, and emotions to link pain or pleasure to whatever we choose. By changing what we link pain and pleasure to, we will instantly change our behaviors.
quotes.Title: American Speaker
quotes.Name: Tony Robbins

quotes.Text: For many years now, I feel like my own body struggle has been linked and connected with women I meet in the world. I think we're in this together.
quotes.Title: American Playwright
quotes.Name: Eve Ensler

quotes.Text: Suffering is the positive element in this world, indeed it is the only link between this world and the positive.
quotes.Title: Novelist
quotes.Name: Franz Kafka

quotes.Text: The bond that links your true family is not one of blood, but of respect and joy in each other's life.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Richard Bach

quotes.Text: All culture, all important culture, is always linked to how people express and experience being alive.
quotes.Title: English Musician
quotes.Name: Genesis P-Orridge

quotes.Text: The importance of money flows from it being a link between the present and the future.
quotes.Title: English Economist
quotes.Name: John Maynard Keynes

quotes.Text: You cannot separate your life and your music and your job; everything's linked.
quotes.Name: Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo

quotes.Text: A chain is no stronger than its weakest link, and life is after all a chain.
quotes.Title: American Philosopher
quotes.Name: William James

quotes.Text: I'm very afraid of being linked with the wrong, rightist, Fascist groups.
quotes.Title: Dutch Politician
quotes.Name: Geert Wilders
